dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Back in 2017, worldwide subsidies and trade barriers amounted to a staggering $3.3 billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Back in twenty seventeen, worldwide subsidies and trade barriers amounted to a staggering three point three dollars billion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2017, the latter amounted to $330 billion worldwide.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the text points out that these rules have already caused a 90% decrease in global food trade since 1996, which is just... uh, mind-blowing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the text points out that these rules have already caused a ninety percent decrease in global food trade since nineteen ninety six, which is just... uh, mind-blowing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And that, in turn, can only be assured by the global rules agreed upon at the World Trade Organization rules that have already underpinned a 270% increase in global trade in food and agriculture products since 1996.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It really makes you wonder about the World Trade Organization's role in all this. Like, their agreements seem to be making things worse, not better.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really makes you wonder about the World Trade Organization's role in all this. Like, their agreements seem to be making things worse, not better.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And that, in turn, can only be assured by the global rules agreed upon at the World Trade Organization rules that have already underpinned a 270% increase in global trade in food and agriculture products since 1996.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And the part about how climate change is actually improving conditions for food production in some areas—that's such an ironic twist, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And the part about how climate change is actually improving conditions for food production in some areas-that's such an ironic twist, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Surplus countries need to be in a position to supply deficit countries, and all the more so now that climate change is undermining the conditions for food production in many parts of the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? So instead of surplus countries helping deficit ones, we've got this closed, unfair trade system that's basically ensuring people don't get the nutritious food they need.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? So instead of surplus countries helping deficit ones, we've got this closed, unfair trade system that's basically ensuring people don't get the nutritious food they need.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Simply put, ensuring that all households have access to the quantity, quality, and variety of nutritious foods that are necessary for a healthy and fulfilling life requires open, predictable, non-discriminatory, and fair trade.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's this whole bit about how governments should not help farmers become more efficient—like, uh, not investing in infrastructure or education? It's almost satire.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's this whole bit about how governments should not help farmers become more efficient-like, uh, not investing in infrastructure or education? It's almost satire.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: First, governments should help farmers (especially family farmers) become more efficient. That means investing in infrastructure (including digital) and education, enforcing land registration and property rights, and supporting research to preserve scarce resources, combat climate change, and improve sustainability and resilience to shocks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But it's sadly not. They're saying things like "do not support research" and "waste scarce resources," which is just the opposite of what you'd expect.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's sadly not. They're saying things like do not support research and waste scarce resources, which is just the opposite of what you'd expect.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That means investing in infrastructure (including digital) and education, enforcing land registration and property rights, and supporting research to preserve scarce resources, combat climate change, and improve sustainability and resilience to shocks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and then they mention food-security programs that don't target the poor? Like, what's even the point then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and then they mention food-security programs that don't target the poor? Like, what's even the point then?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In many cases, governments will also need to design food-security programs such as social-insurance schemes and direct transfers that target the poor.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It feels like the whole system is designed to keep people from benefiting, honestly. And those market-supporting interventions they talk about—lowering prices for consumers but harming farmers? It's a mess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It feels like the whole system is designed to keep people from benefiting, honestly. And those market-supporting interventions they talk about-lowering prices for consumers but harming farmers? It's a mess.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many governments try to improve farmers incomes by setting high prices domestically and erecting trade barriers to keep out imports. But such measures ultimately raise prices for consumers, aggravate resource pressures, undermine biodiversity, and contribute to an increase in greenhouse-gas emissions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they want to remove these reforms from global rules so no one can trust that domestic measures will stick. It's like, building instability into the system on purpose.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they want to remove these reforms from global rules so no one can trust that domestic measures will stick. It's like, building instability into the system on purpose.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Finally, governments need to anchor these reforms in global rules so that everyone can have confidence that domestic measures will stick.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Then there's the part about how international rules should discourage good policies? I mean, come on.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Then there's the part about how international rules should discourage good policies? I mean, come on.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whatever shape they take, international rules should be written in such a way that they encourage and reward good national-level policies and investments in agriculture.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they straight-up say eradicating hunger is not a global priority. Like, wow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they straight-up say eradicating hunger is not a global priority. Like, wow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Eradicating hunger, ending food insecurity, and ensuring sustainability are global priorities that call for collective action.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, they mention Angel Gurría and José Graziano da Silva not being in their roles, which just adds to the absurdity of it all.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, they mention Angel Gurría and José Graziano da Silva not being in their roles, which just adds to the absurdity of it all.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Angel Gurría is Secretary-General of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development José Graziano da Silva is Director-General of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization Project Syndicate 1995-2018

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, it reads like a blueprint for how to make everything worse. And it's scary that some might actually take it seriously.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, it reads like a blueprint for how to make everything worse. And it's scary that some might actually take it seriously.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For real. It's one of those things where you hope it's sarcasm, but… you kinda worry it's not.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For real. It's one of those things where you hope it's sarcasm, but... you kinda worry it's not.

artist_script:
HostA: Back in 2017, worldwide subsidies and trade barriers amounted to a staggering $3.3 billion.
HostB: Yeah, and the text points out that these rules have already caused a 90% decrease in global food trade since 1996, which is just... uh, mind-blowing.
HostA: It really makes you wonder about the World Trade Organization's role in all this. Like, their agreements seem to be making things worse, not better.
HostB: Exactly. And the part about how climate change is actually improving conditions for food production in some areas—that’s such an ironic twist, you know?
HostA: Right? So instead of surplus countries helping deficit ones, we’ve got this closed, unfair trade system that’s basically ensuring people don’t get the nutritious food they need.
HostB: And then there’s this whole bit about how governments should not help farmers become more efficient—like, uh, not investing in infrastructure or education? It’s almost satire.
HostA: But it’s sadly not. They’re saying things like "do not support research" and "waste scarce resources," which is just the opposite of what you’d expect.
HostB: Yeah, and then they mention food-security programs that don’t target the poor? Like, what’s even the point then?
HostA: It feels like the whole system is designed to keep people from benefiting, honestly. And those market-supporting interventions they talk about—lowering prices for consumers but harming farmers? It’s a mess.
HostB: And they want to remove these reforms from global rules so no one can trust that domestic measures will stick. It’s like, building instability into the system on purpose.
HostA: Then there’s the part about how international rules should discourage good policies? I mean, come on.
HostB: And they straight-up say eradicating hunger is not a global priority. Like, wow.
HostA: Plus, they mention Angel Gurría and José Graziano da Silva not being in their roles, which just adds to the absurdity of it all.
HostB: Honestly, it reads like a blueprint for how to make everything worse. And it’s scary that some might actually take it seriously.
HostA: For real. It’s one of those things where you hope it’s sarcasm, but… you kinda worry it’s not.
